Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GEM: Plasma Sheet Instabilities prior to THEMIS Substorm Expansion Onsets
Award.AbstractNarration: This project contributes to the Geospace Environment Modeling (GEM) Focus Group on the early stages of the onset of a magnetospheric substorm. It will systematically analyze the plasma instabilities of the pre-onset, near-Earth plasmasheet substorm events. The plasma sheet conditions will be reconstructed using magnetohydrodynamic simulations with the OpenGGCM MHD code. Once the plasmasheet configuration is known, it will be possible to examine the stability of the configuration to macroscale instabilities such as ballooning, kink, and tearing modes. Both analytical eigenvalue methods and MHD simulations will be used in the stability analysis. The project will examine the signatures and consequences of the plasma instabilities and compare the results with observations made by the NASA THEMIS mission. The linear and early nonlinear instabilities of the plasmasheet during substorm growth phase are the keys to understanding the initial stage of the substorm expansion onset. The accuracy of the stability analyses relies on the detailed knowledge of the plasma sheet configuration model. THEMIS substorm observations will provide more input conditions and constraints that will enable the OpenGGCM simulation to reconstruct a sequence of accurate and realistic plasma sheet configurations during the substorm growth phase. The stability analysis will help resolve many remaining controversies on the onset process and bring in new perspectives on the substorm onset problem. The project will help provide quantitative interpretation of THEMIS substorm events, and will bridge the gap between theory, analysis and observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. First time analysis and identification of ballooning instability in the global MHD simulation of a realistic substorm event.

Both simulation and analysis indicate that ballooning instability is first initiated by the closed field line stretching near a minimum Bz location associated with the formation of a bipolar flow along x around 10 to 11 Re in the near-Earth plasma sheet. The most unstable region coincides with the equatorial crossing locations of the most stretched flux tubes. The ballooning growth of the most unstable region is further enhanced on those most stretched closed field lines Earthward of the neutral line following the formation and the tailward recession of a plasmoid.

The development of the pre-onset plasma sheet configuration and their associated ballooning properties demonstrate a close correlation between the breaching of ballooning instability criterion and the initial onset of the substorm event in timing. The most robust ballooning growth is initiated around 11 Re in a narrow near-Earth region. That narrow ballooning unstable region moves tailward following the recession of a bipolar flow pattern and a subsequently formed plasmoid. The narrow region reaches the most ballooning unstable state near 15 Re when the configuration evolution approaches the initial expansion onset. The maximum ballooning growth rate is estimated to be nearly Alfvenic, with a characteristic time of about 5s. These predictions from our ballooning analysis have been further confirmed for the first time from our global MHD simulation of the dynamic evolution of ballooning instability near neutral sheet well before the initial substorm expansion onset.

2. First time mapping between auroral finger structure and the onset of ballooning instability in the near-Earth magnetotail from global MHD simulation of a realistic substorm event.

To find the possible potential footprints of the magnetotail ballooning instability as well as their evolution in pre-onset auroral structures, a time sequence of ballooning instability structures obtained in the global MHD simulation of the realistic THEMIS substorm event as described in the previous achievement, are mapped along the magnetic field lines to the ionosphere region. The resulting pattern is the expected pattern of ionospheric emissions caused by the ballooning mode through magnetotail-ionosphere coupling.

The morphology of the ionospheric signatures is very peculiar. First, the spacing of the "beads"  is approximately 2.2 degrees in longitude. This compares very well to auroral images, both from the ground and from space. Each wave crest is not simply a spot, but elongated in latitude, thus forming small streaks. These streaks all seem to be directed towards a point some 3-4 latitudinal degree to the north such that they seem to radiate from there. These figures do not exactly represent luminosity, thus the shape of these streaks in the real world may be different. Specifically, since the low latitude part of each of the streaks maps closer to Earth, and thus to hotter plasma, compared to the high latitude parts, the visible structure may well look more like a dot. As time progresses, the streaks become more and more distorted, but also stronger, until they merge into a less well defined structure. The similarities to the IMAGE FUV/WIC images of the November 21, 2002 substorm are striking. In particular, the mode grows over several minutes prior to expansion phase onset and "disintegrates" 2 minutes before the substorm expansion phase commences.
